Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes pas très francs de houblon résineux et herbacé et de malt caramélisé. Robe cuivrée et limpide, effervescence assez faible et aucune mousse. En bouche, sans surprise, la bière se montre très mince, mais cest surtout une forte saveur métallique qui dérange. Le houblon napparaît pas très franc. On retrouve des saveurs caramélisées assez fortes, surtout si on tient compte du corps très léger de cette bière. Une expérience intéressante, mais pas nécessairement réussie.

Overall I liked this beer.  Nice hoppy nose with a rich dark colour.  Has flavour up front, but alas it disappears too quickly and is too thin.  But then again what do you expect from a light beer.  One of the better ones.

Little head, semi lasting, dark golden. Nice hoppy nose to the dry side. Light body an medium length. Quite thin/watery and dry/hoppy taste, Actually better than expected. Could be a fav. driving home-beer.

Beautiful full hoppy nose - dry hopped with two of my more favourite varities. Pours a dark brown with nice pillowy head. Taste is strange, but strangely enjoyable. Like diswasher liquid mixed with hop juice and a nice hoppy finish. Pretty good for what it sets out to be - cant really expect any more.
floral, red fruit, bread, hay, red, red, clear, minimal head, tan foam, watery, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation,

old copper colour with a bubbly head and lively carbonation. Smells delicious: lichees, grapefruit and bitter hoppiness. Some zest too. 
Dry and watery with an extremely bitter resin finish! Dies quickly but leaves you a nice refreshing feel.
Surprisingly good considering the low alcohol... first time I drink a low alcohol beer that not only tastes like beer but is actually quite good.

Disgusting watery beer with a nasty bitter after taste. Bordering of undrinkable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml bottled. Dark amber color, light brown head. Aroma is amazing, some floral hops, fruits and caramel, hints of peach and apprricot. Fruity and bitter flavors but not good... To a low alcohol beer is ok, but Ive got a little bit disappointed.

330 ml bottle from batch # 189. Pours a clear chestnut-orange body with a small, light brown head. Peach, apricot jam, light dried fruits, herbs, caramel and mango sherbert on the nose. Whoa! Light to medium body and a thin texture. Fruity and bitter flavors. Ends rather quick and abruptly though the tongue and palate remain dry and bitter. The best low alcohol beer I ever tried.
From a bottle. Pours dark amber with off white head. Aroma of fresh hops. Taste is all hops with a little metallic finish. Thin and bitter.

Bottle at home.
Redbrown with a large beige head, nice lacings. Aroma light malty, heavy hoppy (citrus), druhopped. Flavor medium to heavy bitter, light spicy. Light body, watery, quite lively carbonated!

Clear light brown, rocky beige head. Strong piney, citric, and floral hop aroma, with some faint caramelly malt notes. Light body, medium carbonation. Bone dry, rough bitterness, the caramel malt brings just a little relief.

Det här är en väldigt svår öl att bedöma eftersom den har mycket större begränsningar än alkoholhaltiga öl har. Men den här ölen är okej om vi jämför med andra alkoholhaltiga öl men som alkoholfri öl är den riktigt bra. Humlearomen är trevlig men smaken kommer aldrig riktigt upp i önskad kvalité och kroppen är mer eller mindre obefintlig. men som sagt det här är en riktigt bra alkoholfri öl.

33 cl bottle @ home, rated on 05.06.2011
Dark orange colour, much more dark than I expected. Aroma is basically just hops and hops  just like one would sniff a load of hop cones. Flavour is a bit short with loads of hops with pine aroma. Watery palate. This could work great on a hot summer day.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2016 Bottle from Cork & Cask. Clear amber body with a thin off-white head. Steady carbonation. Faint lacing. Aroma of toffee, chocolate and generic hops. Flavour of caramel, coffee and rust. Thin body with a watery texture. Soft fizz. Smells better than it tastes. Good for a low ABV beer.

Bottle. Tropical fruit and pine hop aroma. Beautifull dark amber with a big lacing tan head. Roasted entry, bitter grains notes and hop bitterness play on the back of the throat, salty, edgy minerals - feels full and chewy on the palate - bravo!. Plentifull hops and a very light chocolate note retronasal.
Flavorfull, nice to drink and actually quite moreish - 
I think it is fair to say that Brewdog solved the problem with the alcohol free beers.

33cl bottle. #388, BBE  12/2011. Poured amber color with a frothy white head. Very citrusfruity hoppy aroma, perfumy notes as well. Flavor is less fruity, with malt and more perfume. Thin of course,  but for a non alco, a very good beer. Could have this any time over most bulk lagers.

Na het lezen van andere beoordelingen op deze site en het etiket ("extremely hopped") waren de verwachtingen gespannen. En ik vind het een mooie ervaring dit bier! Bij het openen van de fles komt je een heerlijke hop- en citrusvruchtengeur tegemoet. Bier ziet er niet zo mooi uit. Helder koperkleurig met een matige witte kraag. De smaak is zoals de geur, zij het iets minder extreem. Hop en citrusvruchten. De nasmaak blijft lang hangen en is bitter, hop en wat mango (dat las ik bij iemand anders en daar kan ik me wel in vinden)

Een lekker bier. Aan de waterige kant, maar voor zon laag alcoholpercentage...een topper.

A dark copperbrown beer with a quite weak and beige head. Aroma is great, tropical fruits, mangos, grapefruits and some pine needles. Taste is medium bittery, tropical fruits, also some mustyness. Overally, taste is very watery and tastes only for hops. Light to drink, but quite nice. Very good non-alc. beer in spite of strong weaknesses, great aroma.

I was not sure what to expect having read all the other reviews. But as I was the designated driver I thought Id give this low alcohol brew a chance. Its certainly the best low alcohol beer Ive ever tasted and beats most of the "run-of-the-mill" full strength beers Ive ever tasted too. So, if you are looking for something that satisfies but doesnt put you over the limit to drive home this comes highly recommended.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2012 Bottle. Dark amber colour with an off white head. Massive hoppy aroma. Flavour is also full of hopps together with a light fruity note. Thanxx for a great and drinkable low alcohol beer :-)))

Beer-scented water. Utterly pointless. Such a weak flavor and no real presence in the mouth. The whole time I was asking myself "why?" I understand the functional purpose of low alcohol beer, but that cannot excuse what I tasted.

Bottle.  Big head on dark copper.  Looks great for .5%. Smells amazingly great; doubly so for lo ABV. Good malt flavor. Light but solid malt base. Hoppy hoppy hoppy. Probably the best under 2% beer I have had.  Makes being a designated driver something to look forward to!!!

Bottle @ BrewDog Edinburgh
Appearance - Chestnut brown, large white bubbly head that dissipates, reasonable lacing.
Aroma - Grassy hops, some citrus hops, quite like 5am saint.
Taste - Very watery, grassy hops, no malt, dishwater. Awful flavour.
Palate - Grassy, very watery, dry finish, lingering, bit metallic. Very thin body. Moderate carb.
Overall - Looks good in the glass, aroma not bad. Very poor taste and thin watery palate - I just couldnt finish the bottle. Easily the worst beer they do - even Bud is better than this!

Bottle, batch 388, best before 19-12-11.  Wow, right out of the bottle, huge piny nose with the dank and lots of very pronounced earthy and forresty notes, heavy citrus (grapefruit) and cracker.  A ton of resin and oil.  Deep amber pour with a delicate but rocky tan head.  Taste is extremely bitter, not a stretch to say its the bitterest beer Ive had, pound for pound, and at first I had doubts about finishing it.  Body is lightish and extremely dry, has a scratch grainy quality, and the bitterness in the aftertaste reminds much more of brutal espresso aftertaste, maybe a little mocha.  Lightly metallic but with nice woody overtones and light papery undertones (theres absolutely no doubt that Centennial and Simcoe were heavily used here, and Id guess Amarillo for the dank).  Tongue stripping and a little rubbery.  If anything, this proves there are significant benefits to balance.  I wonder if Id like this more if Id been a smoker, or if theyd added some lactose, or if Ill come around after some more experience; its not extreme to the point where Id dare someone to drink it for the look on their face, its just in that gimmick territory where theres no desire to repeat even a few ounces.

Pours dark bronze. 3 fingers of tan head, but it quickly disappears. Lovely smell of hops. Mouthfeel is watery, almost no aroma. Bitter ending. Almost like carbonated water. Not good - got my hopes up from the scent though...

Bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on September 16. Pours dark brown with a very small white head. Smell is fresh, hoppy and filled with fruit like mandarin oranges and pineapple. Taste is refreshing with a very light mouthfeel. Theres a fresh bitterness from the hops but I expected more considering the smell. There is also some ash. Nice and refreshing for a low-alcohol brew.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 Bottle 330ml. A clear amber colour with an average off-white head. Good lacing. An aroma of malt, caramel and citrus. The taste is medium sweet and really bitter. A medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a long finish.

Kastanjefärgad öl med beige skum. Härlig doft med aprikoser, citrus och lite tallbarr. Med tanke på den låga alkoholhalten så är det inte så konstigt att kroppen är lite tunn och vattnig. Dock en ordentlig humlebeska som är ganska trevlig med grape och citron.

Bottled. Pours clear, amber with a meium sized off-white head, leaving some good lacings on the glass. Nice hoppy nose with citrus and pine. Sligtly sweet flavour of citrus, pine, caramel and fruity notes. Light to medium bodied, watery texture and average carbonation. A very drinkable non alcoholic.

Not a bad go at a low-alcohol ale at all, and I went in expecting nothing to come from the hype.  Unsurprisingly frail on the nose; nothing but hops (no alcohol sweetness or other malty flavour).  In the mouth its immediately more watery than any fuller-strength IPA, but the hops kick in quickly, coating the tongue in an oily bitterness, with a bit of citrus lingering on the aftertaste.  As the glass got lower it got more enjoyable as the palate adjusted to the lack of complexity in the body.  Quite drinkable Id say, and I would seriously consider it as a summer drink to enjoy with a clear head if it werent so damn pricey here in New Zealand.
Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, caramel and rather hoppy - grapefruit and pine needles. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 070811
Bottle. Clear amber/brown with small off-white head. Flavour malt, hops, little watery and bitter.

Bottle shared by obguthr at Butters Slutfest 2.0, Richmond, VA, 4.23.11. Pours a hazy amber color with a medium sized creay tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of fruity, citrus hops and some caramellish malts. The taste is bitter hops, citrus, apple and pale caramellish malts. Medium bodied. Wow. Nice for what is practically a NA beer.

Bottled.  A muddy brown coloured beer with a massive rocky head and lacing.  Lots of hops in the aroma.  Standard sharp BrewDog aroma with good citrus and pinsy notes.  Very bitter in the mouth, but with added brown paper bag low alcohol taste.  Too bitter for everything else to gel.  Not overly satsifying.

Bottled. The aroma has citrus, vegetables and some malt. Clear, amber coloured beer with a slight off-white head. The taste is bitter, and very hoppy. Light bodied, bit watery. Very drinkeable almost no alcohol beer.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2012 Bottle at BrewDog bar Edinburgh. Visibly, beautiful, flitting in circles around s the lampshade. Smell is slightly of carrion, tastes of...oh, hold on. Sorry, that was a fly I saw zipping around in the bar. That simple confusion between a fly buzzing in the sky and this beer may go some way to explaining how gash it is. Pours an unusual (Im told) dark brown. Interesting aroma of hops. Its thin and watery, and tastes of bland hoppy water. To its credit, it has the refreshing quality if ice water. Unfortunately, Id rather have ice water, as it doesnt have the unrefined, ugly hop attack. I hoped to like this as I was intrigued by the concept, and am often an apologist for BrewDog. But its just eww.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2011 Amazing big and rich hops aroma with hints of fruit, including peach. Fruity flavor with a very clear hoppy bitterness. But because of the low alcohol content, the body gets a little light. Despite this, the beer is incredibly tasty and easy to drink. Best low alcoholic beer I ever tasted. Tastes even better than many ordinary beers, good job Brewdog!
Very nice taste, fantastic smell. Little bit watery (but way less then I had expected) but very bitter. Unbelievable mouthfeel for only 0.5 ABV.

[330ml bottle from Utobeer, London] Pours chestnut-auburn with a large, craggy, lasting beige head.  Gorgeous tropical fruit aroma.  On tasting its incredibly watery, with a moderate fizz and a hefty bitterness (although its not quite as mouth numbing as in the original 1.1% version).  Bitter brown water is the impression for much of the way through, until an earthy gravy makes a fleeting appearance in the finish followed by a lasting taste of flowers.  Its still weird, but it lacks the intensity of the 1.1% original version, thus making itself rather pointless in comparison.

Darkish brown with a foamy off white head which falls apart quickly. Extremely hoppy, with citrus galore and also cereal, key lime pie and basement. Very promising. Taste is very dry, like they took all the bitter white from lemons. Very light bodied but enough flavour to satisfy. Aftertaste, well, just dry again and maybe some mango. By far the best low alcohol beer Ive rated but clearly one sided and missing the body of an alcoholic beer. Would have this any time over a softdrink! Keep up this work, BrewDog. (33cl bottle, 2,00 EUR?)

I was very eager to try this one. Its very low on alcohol, but its from Brew Dog so i did expect a non-boring beer.
They kinda lived up to that. Colour is very much what i like.. Bit orange/IPA style colour. The smell: Lovely. Great strong hoppy smell. Taste and mouthfeel were dissapointing. For a low alcohol beer its a very good one. If  this beer had maybe 2% or 3% i think it would be a lot better, but then it wouldnt be low alcohol anymore. Its very watery. Too bad, but this may be my favorite low alcohol beer.

Bottle poured with a generous, lasting thick white head, the beer is a golden-amber colour. Lots of floral hops on the nose, some bitterness and more hops to taste although the beer is thin due to the small malt bill. The mouthfeel is a little resinous. Im yet to try a better low abv beer.

330 ml bottle. Rating #1300.
Pours a deep copper colour with a frothy white head. Aroma of pure, very strong floral hops, nothing else. Flavour of strong floral hops, pine needles, mild caramel and some floral notes. Light bodied with a dry mouthfeel and a mouthdrying bitter finish. Great.

Mild aber bestimmt hopfiger Geruch, der sich im Antrunk nur teilweise widerspiegelt. Stattdessen ist das Bier trocken und übertrieben bitter, was durch das Fehlen anderer Aromen noch um ein vielfaches stärker erscheint. Der Hopfen kommt darin kaum zur Geltung, die mächtige Bitterkeit erschlägt alles. Trockener Abgang, bei dem man die Augen zusammenkneifen muss. Gelungenes Experiment, für 0,5% bekommt man einiges geboten. Aber eine so krasse Bitterkeit ist in Teilen kaum auszuhalten! 10/7/1/7/9/8

A good hope nose reminiscent of 5am saint and initial happy taste. You are them hit by the bitterness and with no malt body to back it up it tastes very watery and thin. A good happy aftertaste. Interesting experiment.

Bottle. Dark copper, thin offwhite head. Smells of malts herbs and flowers. Miss some malts and sweetness in the body. Good hoppy and floral finish. Though its unbalanced its probably the most interesting non alcohol ive tried

330mL bottle.  Pours clear light amber with a small off-white head that settles out slightly, some sparse lacing.  Aromas of malt, caramel, toast, citrus and pine.  Not a lot of flavour but the hops and malt acquit themselves reasonably well given the circumstances.  With low sweetness the mild bitterness takes over.  Woody and toasty, and a little carbonic.  Light bodied and thin of course, a bit watery, average carbonation thats very slightly creamy and a fairly long finish.

33cl bottle. It pours a amber/brown colour with steady bubbles and a good head. The nose is of pine, grapefruit and grapefruit pith. The taste is what I imagine a hop tea would resemble. The palate is light to medium and then it disappears. It needs alcohol to balance it. Overall, wouldnt have another but not the worst low alcohol beer Ive had.

Bottle sampled at Slutfest 2.0.  Pours clear copper with a small, fizzy beige head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is average malt (straw, meal), heavy hops (citrus, floral, pine), and notes of soap.  Flavor is average malt (straw, meal), heavy hops (citrus, floral, pine), and notes of soap  Light body and warmth, medium carbonation with a dry finish.
Sampled at Slutfest 2.0.  Hop tea.  Balanced and bitter.  Complex hop profile of green hops and good lingering hop bitterness.  Watery and hoppy.  Good for what it is.

Well whadya know, it is actually possible to make a good low-alcohol beer! The first impression is close to flawless: a dark golden hazy body with a large, long-lasting off-white head that leaves excellent lacing. I have to agree with Brew Dog: the aroma is insanely hoppy, with pine, resin and herbs. The same goes for the taste: a massive hoppy bitterness. But of course, you cant kill the alcohol without being punished: the body is very, very thin with a watery texture. Soft carbonation. [33 cl bottle, courtesy of mfroseth]
Bottle. Clear nut brown body, with a large off-white head. Aroma-taste: strong pine, citrus, leather with a strong bitter finish. Very thin bodied, with moderate-high carbonation.
bottle. deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, apricot, citrus. Flavour is sweet, apricot, malt, hop, citrus. Nice low alcohol.

Tasted 2011-04-18. As my 600th rating I chose this, the best non-alc beer, weve been able to find (the wife is preggy, so shes off the hard stuff). It pours unclear, brown/orange with off white head. It has a very hoppy aroma with notes of toffee. It has a rather weak taste, but still its quite tasty. Moderately bitter finish. Even though its a bit watery, it actually ranks up there with some of the good, boozed ones for me. Thumbs up!

33 cl bottle at home. Clear amber color, nice off-white head. Aroma has lots of hops, like an IPA! Flavor has fine bitterness from the hops, but the body is thin, as expected. Very good low alcohol-beer.
Didnt realise it was only 0.5% before I opened the bottle but tasted ok for something that low, clear amber body with short head, resiny aroma, grainy and pine in the taste.
Bottle at beer temple in Amsterdam. Bitter and hoppy but certainly missing something, good for what it is

0.33 l bottle from Systembolaget, thanks hanniku! Amber color. Strong citrusy, herbal, orangey and piney hop aroma. Dry and very bitter taste, hard minerally bitterness which lingers forever. Nice aroma but tastes like soda water with bitterness extract.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2011 Bottles from BrewDog Aberdeen & Appellation Wines. Hoppy aroma. Medium brown colour with a big foamy head. Dry hoppy flavour. This is more like a good IPA rather than an low alcohol beer. One of Brewdogs best and by far the best low alcohol beer.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget, batch 283, BB 04-19-11. Sampled on March 31, 2011Clear brown color, big lasting fluffy off-white head. Hoppy, citrus, intense, lemon, harsh scent. Mainly bitter taste, doesnt linger that much, Some harsh grainy dry bitter aftertaste at more subtles levels though. Thin mouthfeel. High bitterness, though short.

330ml bottle. Pours a medium copper/orange, with a quite big head. Very hoppy, spicy aroma, lots of apricots and tropical fruits, mango, earth. Dry, light bodied, high bitterness. The taste is a minor hop explosion, but without the malt backbone to support it. Interesting as a low ABV beer, but otherwise quite unbalanced. (2011-02-08)

Bottle from Brewdog Online Store. Pours dark golden with a good white head. Very hoppy and somewhat piney both on the nose and palate. A little watery, but seems more balanced than the 1.1% version. Nice bitter finish.
Bottle at Beer Temple. Nice amber body with small head. Nose of hops and pines but grainy too. Taste is hoppy and grainy but low alcohol makes it rather mellow. Nice bitter in the finish.
Bottle. Amber color. Oily hops and pineapple in the aroma. Watery flavor, but well hopped. Oily hops, glue, some tropical fruit. Shortish hoppy finish. Love the aroma!

33cl bottle. Pours an dark amber color with a huge white head. Good lacing foam. Aroma is hoppy with piney flavors. Taste is resiny and spicy. Light bitterness. Almost water-like body. Interesting beer though.

[3/2/11] Bottle at Beer Temple in Amsterdam. Clear amber color with a medium white head. Great floral hops aroma with lots of citrus. Flavor has some graininess but is mostly packed with lots of piney and somewhat citric hoppy bitterness. Light-medium-bodied. Good stuff, definitely the best 0.5% Ive ever had, and has more character than a lot of big IPAs.

Light caramel/amber colour, clear, no bubbles and frothy tan head
nice big piney hop aroma
very thin and fizzy
mouth drying hoppiness w/ more of a fizzy finish than a bitter one
interesting for a .5% but not very good at all
Bottle from Systembolaget. Dark copper colour and off-white head. Very nice hoppy aroma. Dry taste is moderately bitter from the hops. Watery mouthfeel. Not bad for low alcohol.

330 ml bottle, batch 189, best before 7/21/2011.  Not sure how fresh this is, but Ill drink it anyway.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours a clear reddish/amber color with a half inch off-white head.  Head retention and lacing are both decent.  Aroma is grassy and a bit of citrusy (grapefruit) hops, and some bready malt.  Unfortunately the taste isnt as nice as the aroma.  It tastes like bitter grassy hops, but not much else.  The bitterness isnt exactly nice, but for a beer that has just 0.5% ABV, at least it does have some taste to it.  Moutheel/body is light/medium, its a little bit slick and has good carbonation.  Drinkability is OK, its not hard to drink at all.   It was nice to try this brew, and would try it again if I had a chance to.
Bottle batch 283. Pours amber with a large head. Very nice aroma, the Amarillo really comes out good. Wonderfull hoppy light (in alchohol) beer. Thanks brewdog! :)
Bottle.Pours deep amber with a small off-white head.Aroma of peach, citrus, grapefruit, floral hops and malt.Flavor is sweet and bitter with a watery mouthfeel.Average carbonation.Nice hoppy low alc.

Bottled. 
Dark copper colour with creamy beige head. The smell reminds me of the thermal baths in Budapest, the sulphur aroma is incredible. Mouthfeel is lively and milky and the beer is dry from start to finish. There is an initial chocolate touch that vanishes quickly. Early bitterness that lasts long. Very light bodied.
amber with small white head - aroma is hops - taste is weak malt and a lot of hop bitterness - long hoppy finish - ok, but a little to much hop dominated, lacks malt balance

Tea and orange peel nose. Crystal clear auburn, thick yellow head. Dry and bodiless. Well hopped, dominated by black tea and pine, with a greener grass and clover finish. Very dynamic for an NA. This would be my go-to beer, without question, during those times that I cant have alcohol. Unfortunately, it is hard to find.

330ml bottle (Utobeer, London)
7 Lovely hoppy aroma, fruity and crisp.
3 Clear reddy orange, small head
6- Fairly simple hop-oriented taste, barky bitterness, some sweet fleshy fruits, some flap-jacky malts.
3- Thin and watery, palate, crisp carbonation (how can they get that without force carbonating, Im sure 0.5% isnt enough fermentation to get much CO2 into the beer?) Finish is a bit metallic, some iron definitely, spoiling the show. Possibly because of the levels of hopping, the hoppy finish is a bit muddled. 5 characterful hop varieties do _not_ make a beer 5 times characterful, if anything you end up with something that has less character. (C.f. everything louder than everything else.)
10 Before opening, because I abhor the media-whoring BrewDog do, I wanted to hate this. On pouring, and smelling the hoppy vapours I changed my mind and I wanted to like this. Alas on tasting it couldnt deliver what the aroma promised, so was a little disappointed. I suspect Ive been a little generous with the points,in truth. I doubt that any other brewer could make a 0.5% beer any better, but its still short of being actually a good beer.

Bottle. Pours out in a sligtly hazy amber colour with a rich fluffy off-white head. Pleasant fruity and resinous hop aroma of pine. Light-bodied with plenty of bitter and aromatic hops; resin, grapefruit and wet grass. Watery body of course. Resinous and citric medium-bitter finish. Probably the best low alco out there.

Bottle. Iron brown with foamy tanned head. Looks good!
Pretty hoppy aroma, grassy, too bad the taste doesnt do the aroma justice.
For a low alcohol beer its a very good one. Compared to real beers from Brewdog, ill pass.

33cl bottle at a beer friends birthday party
Very hoppy.  very drinkable for a low alcohol beer.  Good job Brewdog!

330 ml bottle. From Malmö, Sweden.
Clear copper colour with tiny off-white head.
Sweetish dark hoppy aroma with lots of bitterness and some maltiness too. You cant say its n/a by the aroma.
Flavour is dark bitter hops. Since theres no alcohol its thin and waterish. Bitterness stays forever. Best n/a beer so far.

First time i drank it i hated it. Tasted like pure resin with perfume chemicals. Then i gave it a try after coming home from a night out and i loved it. Like licking a battery. Weak body of course, but to me this is a tasty and fun alcohol free alternative.

Bottle courtesy Saxo. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Ambr colour. Moderate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Watery palate but still fine regarding ABV. World class brew.

Bottle 330ml at home</br> Pours dark copper with decent white head. Lots of fruits/hops in the aroma. Better fruity taste that quickly disappears. Watery. Proper good for an almost non-alcoholic brew.

This makes my 1000th rating here on ratebeer.
330ml bottle. Body is clear orange copper and the head is just perfectly creamy and little of white. Nose has lots, and  mean a lot, of fruity hops and exotic fruits. Flavor is bitter from al the hops and coms of in a little malty and sweet caramely way.  Aftertaste is short because of the low ABV. Finishes little watery as well. But that is expected with the low alc. ofcourse. Probably the best low alc. brew I ever had.

Bottle 330ml (Batch #90) @ home 
Pours clear dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of fruity hops (grape, lemon) and caramel. Taste is medium bitter. Texture is watery, light body, soft carbonation.

330ml Bottle - Copper brown in colour. Hoppy aroma with pine and spruce detected. Bitter taste with grapefruit, pine and caramel detected. Its not saying much, but this is the most interesting non-alcoholic beer Ive tried.

Bottles shared by plovmand. 
Pours dark amber with a off white head. 
Lovely fresh unripe grape and caramel aroma. 
Flavour is very bitter at first followed by hoppy fruity hints. 
Very thin bodied.

Bottle at the Three Tuns, Bristol. Amber coloured with a rocky, off-white head. Decent hoppy aroma of citrus and pine resin. Flavour of bready malts with some more hoppy character before a dryish finish. A bit thin, but the best low alcohol beer I have tried to date.

I had high hopes for this beer especially when i smelt it. A lovely pine and citrus aroma exuded from the glass. This beer was vewry thin on the palete, with a distinct metalic flavour. Very disappointing.

Bottled (from brewery, BB 01/2011)
Deep amber color, steady beige head. Berryish, ryeish, hoppy aroma. Light to medium bodied. Malty backbone is a bit thin and has ashy and rubbery notes. But beer has nice American type hoppyness with long lingering bitterness. I prefer alcohol in my beer anyway.
355 ml bottle, nice fruity hoppy aroma with a lots of depth. flavour has also nce amount of bitterness and hops. basicly the whole beer is ode to hops.
Humle, humle, humle är stort sätt det som preglar denna härliga låg-alkoholsölen.

Flaske 0,33l fra Vinmonopolet. Lysebrun. Høyt luftig skum. Herlig fruktig aroma. Appelsin. Smaken er litt søt frukt. Blir selvfølgelig litt tynn men sannelig dukker det ikke opp en fin, tørr bitter ettersmak. Nesten grapefrukt. Utrolig.

Bottle.  Golden-amber.  The aroma is mostly woody centennials.  Bitter start, gets woody and with some sweet caramelly malts.  One of the best made, most interesting non-alcs Ive had, although it does finish a bit watery.

Bottle 0,33 from System Bolaget. Dark amber, white laceing head. Nose is pretty non-existent (cold beer). Flavor is pretty mild too, not as hopped as expected. Pine needles, soap. Nothing to back the hops, some malty roastiness. Pretty refreshing, but not exactly a winner. Looks better than tastes.
27.10.2010, 0,33l Bottle. Golden yellow colour with white head. Aroma is hops and bitterness. Nothing else. Very refreshing.

Bottle 0.33l. Pours nice deep red color with a heavy sticky longlasting head. Nose is hoppy as hell with hints of citrus. Tastes quite strong bitter hops, and the sweetness is non-existing. Aftertaste is of hops and quite watery.
Bottle from Systembolaget. Huge creamy head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers, malt and has a slightly watery palate, but still very nice and bitter.

Pours amber with a decent off white head. Aroma is very promising, great (didnt know what was in the glass!), hoppy, citric and herbs. Flavor is then suprisingly not quite what I was expecting. Very hoppy, but flat, dry and citric. Very dry on palate and finishes with a long lived tart bitter aftertaste. Best light beer I ever had.
I love the hay and siturs flavours that goes in both aroma and flavour of this beer. Really creamy head, with a rich body and a long well-balanced aftertaste! A good beer; A great alcoholfree beer!!!

Appearance: 5/5

Almost completely clear ruby with a big fluffy dirty white head with some yellow and grey in it. Looks very nice actually.
Smell: 8/10

Fantastic smell! Lots of fruity hops, passion fruit, pineapple, a hint of freshly cut grass. Great stuff. I take a sip... and the smell changes completely. Im getting some skunky notes now, like boiled vegetables. Its not to overpowering but its there.
Taste: 4/10

Mild taste. Some hops and a bitterness that feels more like a needle then that punch in the face some beers have. Its there but its just picking at your mouth.
Mouthfeel: 2/5

Very thin body, semi-smooth mouthfeel. Medium amount of carbonation.
Comment:

What an interesting beer!  It shocked me with its big fluffy foam and appealing ruby liquid. I could smell it as I was pouring it and it had the smell that would make most IPAs green with envy. However that was the best part of this beer. The taste is basically hoppy water with little to no malt to support it. But that is to be expected by this kind of beer. However I cant help but wonder if there isnt a way to add more body without increasing the level of alcohol. Definitely something to consider for an experimental brew some time in the future.

Anyway back to this beer. I have to say its a very nice low alcohol beer, I would definitely buy it again if I wanted to stay sober. Might be a good choice if I ever have to be the driver.
Peccato perchè laroma e laspetto promettevano bene! appena assaggiata mi è sceso tutto... acqua frizzante luppolata.

Tried on bottle. This is a very interesting idea from the guys at BrewDog, a non-alcoholic beer brewed to suit even the most hardcore beer drinkers. The taste is rich, for a non-alcoholic beer, and there is some bitter flavours in there. Dont know if my bottle had been damaged somehow or if there was some residue in the bottom of the bottle but the last sip tasted really weird, almost burnt.

Bottle. It pours a clear, amber body and a small, beige head leaving lacings. The aroma is gorgeous, like sticking your head into a bag of American hops, but sadly it fades rather quickly, else it would have been at least an 8 for aroma. After a while the slightly toffee-ish malts appear and gives a sort of balance to it, and a faint roasted note too. Its quite thin on the palate, but not really thin. Nicely carbonated too. Theres lots of tropical fruits and green pine cones in the flavor, enough bitterness to provide great drinkability, and also some bready, caramel malts and a little roasted touch. The finish has pine cones and a pleasant bitterness, the malts left in the background. It drinks better than the 1.1% edition, and is equally damn good for a beer at this strenght, would have been fun having them side by side. Although my rating is higher for the 1.1%, I think Ill choose this one as my favorite. 101001

"Hopped mineral water" ho letto da qualche parte, e mi sembra la definizione più adatta per questo esperimento davvero infelice di BrewDog (fosse lunico..); niente corpo, niente malto, niente di niente, solo un gran luppolo (lamaro è bello potente anche se sono solo 45 IBUs... è da solo!), sembra acqua tonica al luppolo. Non riproverò.

330ml bottle, batch no. 90, from Vinmonopolet Langnes Tromsø. Clear, golden-brown body. Gradually declining, off-white head leaving spotty lacing behind. Fresh hoppy aroma of fruit and flowers. Raw dry hop bitterness in flavour without any finish whatsoever. Thin and empty on the swallow, but still a very decent non-alcohol beverage. Shared with Leif and Magne, Sommarøya 24.09.2010.
After finishing my twelfth bottle of Nanny State I thing I might start to see the point - Its all about the hops, right?

Bottled from Systembolaget
Deep golden. Small white head.
Fruity, grassy, hoppy aroma.
Very thin body. Unbalanced high and dry bitterness.

Bottle. Brown-orange/russet. Nice head. Aroma is bright hops. Orange pulp, cedar, candied orange and some ginger. Fizzy palate. Soda-like with very high carbonation. Very nice. Solid bitterness from chicory, tree bark, burnt nut skins. Long bitter finish. A ton of fun, and very very impressive brewing.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet of all places.
Strong hopy aroma, like herbal tea-
The flavour is more like a hops extract than a beer, with loads of herbs and mints in it. Still, another way of going where ni\o beer hasgone before.

Gusher. Medium white head. Amber body with carbonation. Intense tropical fruit, resin and catnip aroma with wooden oily citrus notes. Bone dry resiny chalky salty taste of cold tea and wood. Mild mouthfeel. Light body. Dry salty marmite aftertaste with dandelion and resin notes. Did not enjoy. (0.33l, wine monopoly, Oslo.)

33cl bottle from Systembolaget. Best before 2011-07-21. Batch 189. I was very excited to see that the mad scottish brewers had released a new and updated version of Nanny State, not only lowering the ABV but also the IBUs. Like the previous version it poured an amber colour with a big, slightly creamy head and some carbonation. The aroma is very hoppy with notes of citrus and assorted tropical fruits like mango, kiwi, peaches and perhaps some toffee. Very promising. The first impression upon tasting is that its very thin and watery. A bit disappointing really. Some hops and tropical fruits again. Also notes of malts and either toffee or light caramel. Very short and thin aftertaste. Overall this was a disappointing beer. After the wonderful and promising aroma it fails to deliver in the flavour department.

Fruity, exciting smell. Taste is very bitter, but I find myself enjoying it still, kinda. Aroma is lots of peaches and mango, with some... old shoes? Interesting as far as non-alcoholic beers go, but I doubt Ill buy it again.

Hahaha! This is so funny! Making a beer thats hoppy enough to twitch hardcore IPA fans, carrying a payload of 0,5 % ABV! :-D Bottle, pours a cloudy dark hazel body with a big off-white head. Aroma and taste is piney, fruity hops, accentuated against the near-watery body which makes it pretty brutal. Tastes a bit like an Alpha Dog with the treble cranked up to the max (the bass being the malty sweetness). A fun, original idea from the boys at BrewDog.
Bottle. Thanks to Craig. Pours a dark brown color with a large white head. A sweet hoppy nose, some caramel. The taste is a nice hoppy pine flavor, some caramel and toasted malts. Very flavorful

0.33L bottle. Firm near-white head. Body is clear, deep gold to pale amber. Strong and inviting hop nose, tropical and citrus. Floral notes. Taste is heavily bitter, or feels heavely bitter, due to the skinny malt body. Some fruity flavoring hops, and most of all, edgy and resiny bittering hops. Unattractive notes of minerals and medicine. Quite rough on the palate. Smells nice, taste is totally out of balance.
Bottle fro Vinmonopolet. Pours clear bronze with a big nice looking tan head. Big fruity hops aroma, mango and peaches. Taste is chemical, like drinking liquid metal, more watery than water. Awful.

Bottle, batch 99. Pours golden brown, almost amber, with some cloudiness. Has a good head, and medium carbonation. Hoppy aroma, with a sharp perfume overtone. Not much texture or body, and it feels almost watery at first. The hop kicks in after a while, but has a perfumeish feeling. This also adds to the metallic acidity all to common in low alcohol beer. As the perfumed, metallic feeling fades, a surprisingly good, long after taste unveils adding to the overall experience.

Bottle. Reddish amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma: Fruity and citrusy hops, rather nice actually. Flavor: Not so nice. Lots of hops, but not very fruity, more of wood, grass, grapefruit-peel and tea-like tannins. Very harsh and dry bitterness with almost no sweetness what so ever. Thin body. Didn´t finish the bottle.

It looks great with a orange-brown body and a light beige head. Smells good to with a lot of fruity hop action going on, but already on the nose you can tell this is missing something. Really thin body and the little malts that are in there are outpowered by all the hops. A rather unpleasant metallic bitterness. I like the idea, but it would be better if they went easier on the hops.

330 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a medium sized, light brown and foamy head. Has a amber/brown colour. The aroma is hops, hops and hops. Its fruity with notes of citrus, passion fruit and grass. The taste is bitter with a hoppy ending. The mouthfeel is light and a bit watery. Great for a low alcohol beer, but it would probably be better with a higher ABV.
330ml bottle. Dark copper body with beige head. Strong aroma of herbs and citrus. Taste of grape and shampoo water. Medium aftertaste. Would maybe be better with 5-6% alcohol...

330 ml bottle, from the n/a selection of Vinmonopolet. ABV is 0.5%. Amber colour, big head, slightly off-white. Lovely aroma of fruity and piney American hops. Thin moutheel. The flavour is all American hops throughout, with a very pronounced bitterness in the finish - 45 IBU sounds not shockingly high, but with a beer this thin, it is. The aftertaste is too bitter and medicinal.

Bottle at home 2010-09-05
AR: loaded with north american hops
AP: amber body, froty volcanic landscaped formed golden sand colored head
F: full body but on the othe hand not, high bitterness, sill heavy in the finish, pine, pineapple, grape fruit

Bottled.  Clear bronze colour, fair sized head. Rich wonderful aroma of mango, lychee and peach. Thin and hard with plenty of sharp metal and exceptionally aggressive resiny bitterness that makes awfully tough to drink. Tastes like perfumed soap with that unpleasant chemical bitterness. Way, way out of balance. A gimmicky N/A.

Bottle. Offwhite thick big bubbly foam that disappears quickly. Clear red brown color. Aroma is a very pleaseant grape and exotic fruit smell. Taste is bitter grapish hops times 10. Thin watery mouthfeel but still refreshing and interesting beer but only for a hophead like myself. For being a really badly balanced beer, I like it! A beer for drinkin´ and drivin´!

Bottle.
Pours mahogny with a light brown head.
Very nice hoppy aroma.
Taste like a very bitter IPA dominated by grapefruity hops.

(Bottle) Reddish brown colour with lasting, pale brown head. Hoppy, fruity nose with notes of fresh hops, pine needles, resin, grapefruit, citrus peel and toasty malt. Hoppy, fruity taste with fresh hops, pine needles, resin, citrus peel and toasty malt. Dry, bitter finish. Rather thin and watery but with an impressive hop character. Far better than any other 0.5% beer Ive had.
Bottle. Golden color, nice beige head. Pleasant hoppy aroma, floral notes, fruity and some citrus. Harsh bitter flavor. Thin and rather bad, actually.

Bottle.

Without doubt the best Low Alcohol beer that I have drunk. Nice aroma of grape and hops. Very bitter taste, the mouth feel was thin but still rather enjoyable. Interesting and unusual beer.

Bottle. Pours amber with a thick white head. Aroma of citrus, pineapple, perhaps peaches. Taste: Huge bitterness, almost too much, also citrus. Unfortunately, it also tastes a bit like water, and the mouthfeel is very thin. The finish is a very long bitterness.
As a non-alcoholic beer, this is head and shoulders above everything else Ive tried.
Intense hop aroma with grass and some citrus. Taste is very light body, however a few sips makes the hops dominate the experience, hence a very very very nice low abv beer! Love it.
Bottle. This beer is a true punk! Thin as a regular low alcohol beer but hoppy as a good american pale ale. Lots of grapefruit. Not in balance, but that fact adds to this beers punky image.

Appearance: Deep amber/red colour, dirty white head, lots of lacing.
Aroma: Hops a plenty! Tropical fruits, citrus, grapefruit, pine, perfume. 
Flavour: Very good hop profile that I like! It cant avoid getting thin though. 
Mouthfeel: It is thin and watery. 
Total: This is a good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 Bottle (33 cl) from systembolaget. Clear light brown, rocky beige head. Strong piney, citric, and floral hop aroma, with some faint caramelly malt notes. Light body, medium carbonation. Bone dry, rough bitterness, the caramel malt brings just a little relief.

BottledPours copper brown with a large and thick head. Loads of hops on the nose;  pine, goose berries, grapefruit. Thin, almost watery mouth feel. Flavour is packed with brutal hops; resin, pine, grapefruit. Very intense and almost too much.

330ml bottle at Musa, Aberdeen. Pours amber, slightly yellow head and well carbonated. Nose; Floral, slight varnish. Taste; thin (but to be expected for this low strength), grassy, weak start with aggressive hoppy finish. Quite bizarre.... unlike anything else Ive tasted, but not in a especially good way.
Bottle at ChrisO "Im Trying to see the Stool" pre GBBF2010 tasting. Lovely nose.  Still not very good in the mouth though.  Thin, but good nose and better than the 1% version I couldnt finish.

Amber with a small but lasting tan head. Aroma of citrus and other fruits, biscuit-y malt and a touch of diacetyl. Thin and dry hoppy flavour. Tea-like watery bitterness in the finish. They took it to the limit. And now a step too far. But you only know the limit after crossing it.
Big, earthy hop aromas.  Medium plus hop bitterness in the flavor.  Quite well balanced, and a significant improvement over the 1.1% version.

From the Bottle at Chris Os pre GBBF tasting, Kensal Rise 31/07/2010
Big hop aroma. Golden amber coloured and hoppy with a hint of dryness and citrus flavour in a floral finish.
Bottled (thanks TBone). Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is fruity, floral and grass. Flavour is fruits, floral notes and quite grassy. Quite thin palate, but brutally hoppy.

Was excited to spot this beer. Aroma is pretty hoppy, faint caramel.  Taste is a strong hoppiness with a far too mild caramel maltiness, no real roastiness to speak of and a total lack of depth- however this is a great first step in moving forward for high flavor beers in low alcohol categories.
Bottle at Chris Os Raise the Roof tasting. Amber pour with an off white head. Herbs and lime in the nose. Very fruity indeed. Unsurprisingly light. Sharp citrus flavours.
Bottle at chrisos pre-GBBF Raise the Roof Shindig 10. Amber with a white head. Nettly aroma. Bonfire taste. Not the most palatable, I fear.

Pours an interesting bright brown/amber. Very weak aroma, hops are almost inexistent unlike her 1.1% sister. Drinkable indeed and fizzy the right, but too much watery and tea-oriented (instead of citric) for my liking. Anyway, surely better than professed low-alcohol industrial shits like Tourtel; a summery beer where malts are distinguishable though.

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks to the Cad.An excellent amber colour with a really impressive off white head and superb condition. Fantastic fresh hoppy snout. Grassy and floral as you like. Not quite so great in the mouth. Missing the excitement factor of the "strong" version but its still pretty good. Lashings of Simcoe, quickly followed with a dollop of Centennial and Amarillo. Effortlessly drinkable obviously. Actually, the more I drink, the better it gets. Light and fruity, just the right level of bitterness. Really good.

Bottled. An amber beer with an orangey head. The aroma has notes of hops as well as lighter notes of malt and citrus. The flavor is very sweet - but lacks malt, and has notes of caramel and a sharp hop edge, leading to a dry hoppy finish. The body is thin. Too much.

Hehe Is this a new style?  LOL!  This bottled brew marked batch 484 best before 01/15/2011 from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized off-white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a softly carbonated transparent dark copper brown colored body. The aroma was hoppy and dough. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a bite in the aftertaste. The thin watery strange flavor contained notes of mild hops. Not one that I would drink again.  But why I ask?  Really why?  Not just because you can I hope!

dark orange, smooth white head.
loads of hops, sligtly flowery hops, in the aroma.
flavor is very hoppy, not much malty base, but some balance for the hops exist. pretty quenching, would be a great low alc beer for at hot summer day.

Fløska.Clear nice golden deep amber colour, small off-whit head. Pleasant fruity well hopped aroma. Ok mouthfeel. Sweet flavour bitter hoppiness, some pine. Very pleasant brew and for such a low alc., really nice.  Gracias Plovamand traer esta de Italia
Bottle. Brown body with a medium off white head. Caramel, peach, citrus and fresh fruit. The flavour is very one dimensional. Brewmash, caramel and citrus hops. Very bitter finish.

Bottle 33cl.@ RBESG10 in bir&fud beershop, Via luca valerio 41/43, 00151 Roma, Italy.Clear medium amber color with a average, frothy - creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, citrus - orange, butter notes. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration, buttery, tea bitter. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100604]

Bottle 33 cl. RBESG Rome 2010. Courtesy of ChristianScheffel. Pours a pretty and warm amber with a beige head. Fresh and fairly intense peach aroma. Light body, thin and watery, some nutty accents and pleasant aroma hops that leave a solid bitterness. Impressive range of flavours in such a small beer. 040610
Bottle @ Bir and Fud beershop, Rome. Pours unclear amber with a small creamy white head and lacings. Nose is various exotic hops. Orange and tropical. Medium bodied.  Amazing for a 0,5% beer.

Bottle Clear copper ale with a quickly dissipating head. The nose is piney, earthy and musky with undertones of leather and caramel. Light-bodied, watery and astringent with jazzy carbonation. Refreshing essence of bitter, earthy, flavorful hops pulls up just shy of heavily bitter. Thin, for certain. Finishes crisp, coarse, and then dry. Since I shy away from anything over .5% abv during the work week nowadays, Id drink a bottle of this every evening with dinner if it were readily available. By a country mile, the best n/a beer Ive ever experienced. Bottle courtesy of darkguardian!

amber colour. light body no alcohol. doesnt present particular aromas because i could only notice a massive presence of hops and a costant bitter flavour. this beer is really drinkable buti suggest it only to those who love really hoppy and bitter beers

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear mahogany with a long lasting white head. Some lacing. Nice looking beer. Nose is terrific with some light caramel and a huge wall of pine and citrus hops. Tastewise it is what it is. Soda water up front with a very faint hint of caramel malt. A light cereal note lingers in the finish. Clean solid bitterness and some light fruitiness from the hops. This beer could be helped by a better selection of flavor hops, because you do notice the lack of malt, there is no denying it. This is a valiant effort though, and by far and away the best NA beer I have ever had, I gave it a high overall score in recognition of its achievement within the style.
ambrata buona schiuma persitente naso lupolato agrumato americano note caramellate lievi astremamnte amara pochissimo corpo tutto luppolo

Bottle. Pours a deep amber with smallish offwhite head. Minimal lacing. Great resiny pine hop aroma with just the faintest sweet malt coming through. Taste wise not much happening. Bitter finish with not much else. Very thin with no malt backbone. Kinda how I imagine hop tea to taste. Somewhat better than other available low abv beers but that is about all.

Bottle, bit thanks to Craig cgarvieuk for this one, consumed 15-04-10   The colour is chestnut brown with an off-white filmy head. Bottle at Pre-ZBF 2010. Dark amber with lasting white head. Big piney and citrusy nose and flavour. Some caramel malt for support. Very thin but easy to drink. Bottle from brewdog online shop. Clear brown colour, large beige chewy head. Aroma is dry, hoppy, tea. Flavour is more malty, dry, fairly bitter, some citrus. A bit less intense bodied, compared to the 1,1% version.

Bottle at T&Ms. Pours a clear brown with a small off-white head. Smells of hops and tea. Dry with aromas of bitter hops, with tiny fruity notes and caramel. Also aromas of tea. Slightly peated notes and ever-so-tiny hints of English liquirish. VERY light bodied. Long dry finish with more caramel notes.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear brown - white head. Tea, light smoked tea, nice medium hoppy, roasted, light nutty, malt bolcher.

Bottle. High creamy and lasting head. Clear dark brown body. Caramel roasted malt honey dried fruit lemon aroma. Hoppy malty heavily carbonated flavor with a long aftertaste. Would not have guessed on such a low alcohol percentage.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense beige head. Floral and sweet aroma. Flavour is herbal and floral with a light citric touch. A bit thin bodied. Citric and bitter end. For a 0,5% beer, its very good, but as others I would prefer the 1,1% version.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with a small off white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel, hops, pine needles, grass and brewmash.
Fruity flavour of hops, grass and pine needles.
Dry hoppy finish.

33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small tan head. Aroma is solid citrusy and grapefruit hoppy. Mild malty and vague butterish touch. Bone dry and bitter, loads of US hops flavours - not as bad a hopssoup as the 1.1 version. Citric and bone dry finish.

Bottle, ordered online from the brewery, 12th Feb 2010. Tawny dark amber colour - looks a bit like whisky - with some cream coloured head. Lots of pine and resinous hop notes on the nose. In the mouth its dry and bitter but as expected lacks much of a sweet malt balance and the palate is naturally quite light. My initial feeling is that it is more drinkable than the 1.1% old version (will do a side-by-side taste soon and will probably re-rate the old one) and if you want the hops of an APA on a school night, then it definitely does the job. Id not drink it ahead of the likes of their Punk or 5AM Saint, but its a million miles more tasty than most low alcohol beers.
